posts.name:
Elvi Caperonis
Elvi Caperonis
posts.content:
𝗪𝗵𝘆 𝗱𝗼 𝗲𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗼𝘆𝗲𝗲𝘀 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝘆 𝗹𝗼𝘆𝗮𝗹 𝘁𝗼 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗲𝘀? 



𝗛𝗶𝗻𝘁: 𝗜𝘁’𝘀 𝗻𝗼𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝘆 𝗽𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗶𝗲𝘀, 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝘀𝗻𝗮𝗰𝗸𝘀 𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗮𝗻𝗰𝘆 𝗼𝗳𝗳𝗶𝗰𝗲𝘀.


Those perks are fun and can improve the workday but don't keep people engaged and motivated in the long run.

What matters to employees is having the flexibility to balance their lives and work.

This means options like working remotely, flexible hours, and understanding managers who get that life happens.

Genuine recognition is also a big deal.

Employees want to feel like their hard work is noticed and appreciated.

It doesn't have to be huge—sometimes, a simple thank you or a shoutout in a team meeting can go a long way.

𝗟𝗲𝘁'𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗿 𝗳𝗮𝗶𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝗻𝘀𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻.

While money isn’t everything, paying employees fairly for their efforts makes them feel valued and respected.

This includes not only their 𝘀𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗿𝘆 𝗯𝘂𝘁 𝗮𝗹𝘀𝗼 𝗯𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗳𝗶𝘁𝘀 𝗹𝗶𝗸𝗲 𝗵𝗲𝗮𝗹𝘁𝗵𝗰𝗮𝗿𝗲, 𝗿𝗲𝘁𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗽𝗹𝗮𝗻𝘀, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗼𝗽𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗲𝘀 to advance in their careers.

𝗜𝘁'𝘀 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗳𝗼𝗰𝘂𝘀 𝗼𝗻 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗺𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘀.

Share your thoughts below.

𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗸 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗻𝗶𝗲𝘀 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗰𝘂𝘀 𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗼 𝗸𝗲𝗲𝗽 𝗲𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗼𝘆𝗲𝗲𝘀 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝘆?

comments.commentText:
Repost if you agree  

𝗟𝗲𝘁'𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗺𝗯𝗲𝗿 𝗳𝗮𝗶𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝗻𝘀𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻. 

While money isn’t everything, paying employees fairly for their efforts makes them feel valued and respected.
People go above and beyond when they are recognized.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Prioritizing flexibility and genuine recognition truly fosters loyalty and engagement among employees. What a crucial conversation!

Imagine combining Postman, your Kanban board, and AI tools into one seamless messaging platform. That’s the genius of OneTab.ai.

Efficiency isn’t just about working harder—it’s about working smarter.delivers. 

Keep up the innovation

posts.name:
Amir Tabch
Amir Tabch
posts.content:
All in 
hashtag
#Leadership: When you’re right…& when you think you’re right

Imagine a
walks into a meeting, slams their fist on the table, & declares, “I’m right, & we’re going all in!” Everyone nods nervously because, well, they look confident. But here’s the twist—being right isn’t about looking confident or yelling louder than everyone else. It’s about knowing when your idea is rooted in solid judgment & when it’s just a bold shot in the dark.

Because let’s be real, going “all in” without being truly right isn’t leadership. It’s gambling with the company’s future.

Being right isn’t about ego; it’s about accuracy.
often mistake their gut instincts for universal truths, but history shows us the cost of unchecked confidence. Consider Blockbuster. They were sure people would never want to stream movies. Enter Netflix. Lesson? Believing you’re right without evidence can turn your company into a case study—for the wrong reasons.

Research by Jim Collins shows that successful leaders embrace what he calls “Level 5 Leadership,” a mix of professional will & personal
. They aren’t just right—they’re carefully right, basing decisions on data, listening to others, & questioning their own assumptions.

When you know you’re right (& have the receipts to prove it), hesitation is fatal. A few examples:

• Steve Jobs: He didn’t hesitate to go all in on the iPhone despite skeptics calling it “just another phone.”

• Indra Nooyi: She doubled down on healthier product lines, betting on a future of conscious consumption.

• You, the reader: Remember that time you ordered pineapple pizza even though your friends mocked you? You stood your ground—& they secretly loved it.

The takeaway? When you’ve done your homework & the data backs your gut, go all in. But—& this is a big but—don’t skip the homework.

Here’s where it gets dangerous: the overconfident leader who assumes they’re right all the time. Research reveals that
is one of the most common leadership pitfalls. It blinds leaders to alternate perspectives & makes them double down on bad decisions.

How to be carefully right:

• Validate your assumptions: Before going all in, test your ideas. Pilot programs & feedback loops are your friends.

• Stay open to dissent: Surround yourself with people who challenge you. The best leaders don’t want yes-people; they want truth-tellers.

• Know when to back off: Being wrong isn’t failure—it’s data. Use it to pivot, not to panic.

Leadership requires
, no doubt. But courage without humility is a recipe for disaster. The difference between a reckless leader & a great one is this: the great one knows they’re right because they’ve done the work, not because they feel like it.

So, when you’re ready to go all in, remember:
is contagious, but evidence is convincing. Be the leader who inspires both.

& if you’re ever unsure, ask yourself: Is this decision based on insight, or am I just hoping pineapple pizza wins the day?
posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Leadership is about informed decisions, not just confidence. Lets champion evidence-based approaches! 🍕📊 #Leadership #Growth

posts.name:
Jamal Hamilton
Jamal Hamilton
posts.content:
I hate telling people what to do.

Especially, on LinkedIn

You know the type:

• Use this opener and book more meetings.
• Write short emails with short subject lines for better responses.
• Outbound is dead, email is dead, cold-calling is dead.

Everything is dead, blah, blah, blah.

There’s way too much telling and not enough showing.

There’s no magic bullet or magic trick.

What works for one person might not work for you.

How many times have we tried a LinkedIn tip that someone swore by, only to see no results?

I believe in trying things out and finding what works best for you.

If it sounds like a hack or trick, it probably is.

You can’t hack your way to hitting quota or making President’s Club. It takes real work and determination to figure things out.

So, take everything you see here with a grain of salt.

Or don’t.

The choice is yours
posts.commentAdded: Great perspective! Emphasizing personal experimentation over generic advice is vital for success. Let’s embrace our unique approaches!

posts.name:
Tom Goodwin
Tom Goodwin
posts.content:
Nokia. Kodak. Blockbuster. Borders.

Remember the relentless tech disruption narrative from 2010?

These companies were cautionary tales, and the question on everyone’s mind was who’s next?

Surely Walmart & Target were doomed, Airbnb would crush Marriott, & Toyota would fall to Tesla, Uber, Waymo, or all three.

Who needed a Gym in the age of Peloton, or Bank when we've got an neoBank.

But then… nothing much happened.

For all the talk of “Disrupt or Die,” “Digital Darwinism,” and “Creative Destruction,” reality turned out far less dramatic.

Yes, Toys "R" Us failed, but that was more about debt.

Sears? Almost gone, but retail bankruptcies are the same rate as they ever were.

Of the Global Fortune 500, only NEW 12 companies were added in the last 25 years, while 324 new arrivals were older companies growing.

Disruption didn’t sweep through industries as we imagined.

Instead, the Internet redistributed distribution costs more than it rewrote the rules of business.

Digital didn’t expand the addressable market as much as we thought.

Digital didn’t change the fundamentals. People value convenience but also trust, reliability, and time-tested basics.

The Real Problem: Operational Apathy and Distractions.

Companies get stuck in their own processes.

They waste energy chasing distractions instead of focusing on meaningful, medium-sized changes that drive efficiency.

The best companies balance innovation with maintenance. They harness technology where it counts—calmly, strategically, and on their terms—not as a reaction to fear, but as a deliberate effort to make money and delight consumers.

It’s not always about inventing new economic rules but using great ideas to make even more sense in a digital age.

-Success lies in delighting customers.
-In maintaining the core while upgrading intelligently.
-In reliability, continuous improvements, and the basics done brilliantly.

And this is where—the sponsor of this post—excels.

They help businesses take control of their IT landscapes by offering third-party support for Oracle, SAP, and VMware systems.

Companies can now reduce the costs and complexity of vendor-provided maintenance, while gaining access to high-quality, personalized support from experienced engineers.

By extending the life of critical systems and addressing challenges like interoperability and vulnerability management, Spinnaker Support empowers businesses to focus on what truly matters—innovation, customer satisfaction, and operational efficiency.

For organizations caught in the endless cycle of costly upgrades or struggling to find the right time for transformative changes, Spinnaker provides a smarter alternative: maintaining the core systems that drive the business, while freeing up resources for strategic growth.

Disruption isn’t everything. Focus, widespread improvements, and customer satisfaction? Maybe that’s the future.

comments.commentText: Nikolas Badminton Boring and reliable wins way more than we want to admit.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Its refreshing to see a focus on operational efficiency and customer satisfaction over fleeting disruption narratives. Well said!
